results.title: The Sixth part of the world
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov was the founder of the Soviet documentary. He headed a group of experimental documentarists who took the name Kinoki, or Kino- Eyes. As a militant theorist he proclaimed the supremacy of what would now be called Cinema-Verite. His films and his theoretical writings have had an enormous and lasting influence on world cinema. “The sixth part of the World” is Vertov’s lyrical cinema poem to the vast expanses of the Soviet Union, grand, complicated, exotic and hugely popular.

results.title: The Sixth day of creation
results.creator_credit: Triangle Productions, Theodora Olembert and Francis Maziere
results.brief_description: On the sixth day God created Man and Beast, and since then the law of the jungle has reigned supreme. All species feed on other forms of life: none of them good or evil - just struggling to survive. The strong shall eat the weak - there is no appeal.

results.title: The Six billion $$$ sell
results.creator_credit: Consumer Reports Films and Carole Kahn
results.brief_description: A combination of comedy, animation and an original pop theme song are used to expose the questionable techniques of TV commercials. Aims to make viewers aware of how advertising can influence attitudes, values and expectations and helps consumers develop a healthy scepticism about advertising. Illustrations of persuasive advertising techniques include promises, giveaways, star endorsements, word games and branch loyalty. Features Billy Crystal.

results.title: The Sitar
results.creator_credit: Hungry Mino Enterprise and James Chimbioio
results.brief_description: Details the origin, history, philosophy, ritual, composition and performance of classical Indian music and talks of its relationship with the Hindu religion. The basic musical form is the raga, and the sitar is now extensively used in this classical style. Enables the viewing of a sitar performance. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: The Sirinumu Dam
results.creator_credit: Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: The building of the Sirinumu Dam on the Loloki river of New Guinea. A secondary supply of electric power was needed to serve industrial and domestic Port Moresby. A complete record of the project from the planning, the purchase of land from the indigenous peoples, the drilling and dynamiting to the final opening of the dam gate.

results.title: The Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior
results.creator_credit: Capital Cities, Sam Strangis and Michael Tuchner
results.brief_description: A docu-drama based on the shocking terrorist attack initiated by the French government on the Greenpeace flagship vessel the Rainbow Warrior. The ship which was the centrepiece of the Greenpeace protest against nuclear testing that was being undertaken by the French in the Pacific, was moored in Auckland in August 1986 when it was blown apart by a bomb blast, killing one of its crew. In this dramatization, Sam Neill and Jon Voight play two polar opposites - a hardbitten cop and a eco-activist, respectively - who team up to track down the bombers uncovering an international conspiracy in the process. Cast also includes Bruno Lawrence and Kerry Fox.

results.title: The Sink
results.brief_description: An experimental film based on “The Mid-Atlantic man” by Tom Wolfe. It compares the class structure of the Western world to an experiment carried out on rats by an American ethnologist in the 1950s. Of a group only a minority live comfortably and happily, the majority are not so fortunate.

results.title: The Singing detective. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, ABC-TV (Australia), John Harris, Kenith Trodd and Jon Amiel
results.brief_description: The second and final volume of a compelling mini-series written by Dennis Potter which merges fantasy, reality and history through a noir-like, musical and surreal narrative entwined around its central character, Philip Marlow (Michael Gambon). He is an ‘out of print’ detective fiction writer who is incapacitated both physically and emotionally by a rare skin disease, waiting for a seemingly impossible healing process to begin in an overworked National Health Hospital while he constructs the plot and imagery of a detective story in his mind, unable to use a pen. ‘The Singing Detective’ seams together three narratives, Marlow’s hospital experiences, the detective novel set in post World War II London that he is half-composing and half-hallucinating, and memories of his wartime boyhood that cross into both his reality and his fiction. Marlow pictures himself as a crooning 1940s detective, wrapped up in an intricate murder case, an image that gradually interplays with his own progress of self-discovery and healing in the real world of his hospitalised condition and his intermittent memories of childhood. In this final part of the mini-series, the clues of his past and the plot twists of his novel begin to piece together, completing the puzzle of Marlow’s own griefs and fears and the detection of the multi-layered and not so fictional mystery he has been composing.

results.title: The Singing detective. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, ABC-TV (Australia), John Harris, Kenith Trodd and Jon Amiel
results.brief_description: The first volume of a compelling mini-series written by Dennis Potter which merges fantasy, reality and history through a noir-like, musical and surreal narrative entwined around its central character, Philip Marlow (Michael Gambon). He is an ‘out of print’ detective fiction writer who is incapacitated both physically and emotionally by a rare skin disease, and waiting for a seemingly impossible healing process to begin in an overworked National Health Hospital while he constructs the plot and imagery of a detective story in his mind, unable to use a pen. ‘The Singing Detective’ seams together three narratives, Marlow’s hospital experiences, the detective novel set in post World War II London that he is half-composing and half-hallucinating, and memories of his wartime boyhood that cross into both his reality and his fiction. Marlow pictures himself as a crooning 1940s detective, wrapped up in an intricate murder case, an image that gradually interplays with his own progress of self-discovery and healing in the real world of his hospitalised condition and his intermittent memories of childhood. When he agrees to talk to a hospital psychotherapist, the clues to all three narratives and their inseparable significance to each other begin to accumulate.

results.title: The Singer and the Dancer
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Council and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: Set in the country, an older woman relives the bitter memories of her past, through her friendship with a younger girl who is experiencing a very insecure relationship with her boyfriend. Winner of several awards including Australian Film Awards and Sydney Film Festival. Cast includes Ruth Cracknell, Elizabeth Crosby, Russell Keifel, Jude Kuring, Gerry Duggan, Julie Dawson, Jane Buckland, Kate Sheil, Rob Steele, Kerry Walker. Photographer: Russell Boyd. Based on a short story by Alan Marshall.
